summary: A throw-statement throws an exception that is provided as an argument thereto.
details: In order to catch a thrown exception, use a Try-Catch Statement.
An uncaught exception will cause the enclosing invocation to terminate.
An uncaught exception will propogate until it is caught.
If an exception is caught by the runtime, then the program will be terminated.
static-checks: The type of argument must be assignable to type java.lang.Throwable.
example-1: module Main in examples;%0A%0A@Start%0Adefun main (args : String[]) : void%0A{%0A    # This example shows how to throw and catch an exception. %0A%0A    try%0A    {%0A        F::println (%22before%22);%0A%0A        throw new Exception();%0A%0A        F::println (%22after%22);%0A    }%0A    catch (ex : Exception)%0A    {%0A        F::println (%22handle%22);%0A    }%0A}
example-2: module Main in examples;%0A%0A@Start%0Adefun main (args : String[]) : void%0A{%0A    # This example shows that an exception can cause an invocation to terminate early.%0A%0A    try%0A    {%0A        F::println (%22before%22);%0A%0A        Main::trouble();%0A%0A        F::println (%22after%22);%0A    }%0A    catch (ex : Exception)%0A    {%0A        F::println (%22handle%22);%0A    }%0A}%0A%0Adefun trouble () : void%0A{%0A    F::println (%22enter%22);%0A%0A    throw new Exception();%0A%0A    F::println (%22exit%22);%0A}
